column3: I have experience in different fields of CS, specifically with Statistical Analysis.

column5: Optimized data-gathering code using Ruby to examine thousands of server checkpoint and compliance standards.
column6: Wrote queries using PostgreSQL to connect multiple relations and further analyze servers and their data fields.
column7: Developed a Power BI dashboard to demonstrate outliers and group/label data for future compliance updates.

column5: Worked on historical transaction data using Jupyter Notebooks for user inflow/outflow analytics and visualization.
column6: Performed multiple statistical tests on gathered data for possible algorithm improvement and outlier detection.
column7: Coded Python scripts for data labelling, cleaning, and extraction for predictive tendency models for hundreds of users.
column8: Used Python libraries: Pandas, Matplotlib, CSV, Numpy, Scipy.Stats, and Seaborn.

column4: Coding Python scripts using JupyterLab for cleaning and parsing over 160k messages spanning through 3 years into dictionaries with efficient tagging
column5: Visualizing tendencies on how frequently messages are exchanged in hourly, daily, monthly, and yearly basis
column6: Calculated the rate in which users send messages, as well as determining the user with the most messages and their ‘busiest’ message sending intervals.
column7: Currently researching/testing SKLearn’s DecisionTrees to classify messages and determine when would they be sent.

column3: The NBA Draft: A Historical-Numerical Approach
column4: Developed a Python script that extracts data from around 4k NBA players and their accumulated counting and computed stats.
column5: Performed t-tests and f-tests using Python’s stats module to compare if different NBA decade players can translate their statistics across different periods of time.
column6: Cleaned and pivoted data with Pandas and prepared a data pipeline to create data animations using Python’s FuncAnimation library.
column7: Created a metric that combines all counting and computed stats that determines which NBA draft class is objectively better. According to Bleacher Report’s studies, the results were 83.3% compatible with their results.
column8: Documented and kept track of all progress with LaTeX. Project was made as part of the MATE4990 course.
